subject: Re: [junit] Could not find class:
msgSnippet: I think reading through this JUnit 4 in 10 minutes will take you a long way:
messageBody:
I think reading through this "JUnit 4 in 10 minutes" will take you a long
way:
http://www.instrumentalservices.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=45&Itemid=52
Google or the JUnit FAQ would have gotten you some answers much faster.

Having that said I see several issues:

1. You need to descide wether you want to use the JUnit 4 or the JUnit 3
style for your tests. If you extend TestCase jUnit will run your tests as
3.X meaning that each test is a public, void menthod, with a name that
starts with test and takes 0 arguments. Annotations will be ignored.
If you want to use the 4.x style then don't extend testcase.

2. As far as I know JUnit 4 methods also need to take 0 arguments and they
can't be static so even if you don't extend TestCase main will not be
identified as a test.

I haven't used jUnit 4 yet so if you want solid answers follow the first
link I posted.
I hope this helps.


On 10/22/06, Magnus <t703093@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
> anybody knows how I can solve this:
>

>
> or
>

>
> But I get errormsg:
>
> "No tests found in TestX"
>

> SimpleTest is (i.e. the directory whicj contains SimpleTest).
>
> My path variables are set right I think:
>
> CLASSPATH:
>
> C:\junit4.1\junit-4.1.jar;.org.junit.runner.JUnitCore;
>
> My classes look like this:
>
> import java.lang.annotation.Annotation;
> //import junit.framework.Test;
> //import junit.framework.TestCase;
> //import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> import static org.junit.Assert.*;

> import java.util.*;
>
> public class X {
> @Test
> public int met (int number) {
> int num = number;
> if (num > 1)
> return num*2;
> else{
> return 666;
> }
> }
> }
>
> ////////////////////////////////////////////////////
>
> import java.lang.annotation.Annotation;
> //import junit.framework.Test;
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> //import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> import static org.junit.Assert.*;
> import org.junit.*;
> import java.util.*;
>
> public class TestX extends TestCase {
> @Test
> public static void main (String args[]){
> X y = new X();
> System.out.println(y.met(1));
> }
> }
>
> I hope someone can help me with this?
>
> Magnus
>
>
>
